results.title: The Robin
results.creator_credit: Donald Eastman, Rosemary Eastman and Gateway Educational Films
results.brief_description: A study of the robin and its relationship with man. Courtship behaviour, nest building and the rearing of young are shown in detail and the differences between migratory and non-migratory birds is explained.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Donald Eastman, Rosemary Eastman and Gateway Educational Films

results.title: Road to the West
results.creator_credit: Alex Ezard, Artransa Park Studios and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The story of the early days of Sydney Cove told by means of historical stills and by the re-enactment of the crossing of the Blue Mountains by Blaxland, Wentworth and Lawson, the resulting development and relics of that period, including the old Court House at Hartley. Today fast transport enables commuters to travel to and from Sydney and the Blue Mountains in less than two hours, passing through towns named after the three explorers.

results.title: Road to independence
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Balla, Ronald Dick and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “The Commonwealth of Nations”.
There is world-wide significance in the planned process by which Britain is helping her colonies master the art of self-government. This concluding film cites recent developments in Ghana, Nigeria, Nyasaland and other colonial territories where political evolution has seen striking progress in recent years. Edgar McInnis analyzes these developments on the basis of two main considerations; and why a ruling power should arrange for its own departure from its colonies; why, once independent, the former subjects should continue to associate with their former master.

results.title: River Murray
results.creator_credit: Alan Harkness, Eric Thompson, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Eltham Films
results.brief_description: Early settlers were plagued by flood and drought along the Murray, today the waters are controlled by the various dams, locks and canals which have been constructed along its course. Includes the Hume Reservoir, Mulwala Canal and the channel at Frenchman’s Creek. Now floodwaters are checked, dry lands irrigated, electric power is generated, useless land can be reclaimed, and the river is navigable from the mouth to a point just beyond Mildura. The film also considers the effect of this system on the development of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia.

results.title: The Rise of nations in Europe
results.brief_description: Lists the pattern of national evolution in France as an example of the growth of nationalism in many European countries. Explains how the increasing importance of artisans and merchants, resulting from increased travel and better tools and manufacturing methods, helped to strengthen the position of the king; and how the greater wealth provided him with funds to carry on wars and create central services. Shows the famous people of the era and many of the critical struggles.

results.title: Riding on air
results.creator_credit: Central Office of Information for Foreign Office and Colonial Office and Editorial Film Productions
results.brief_description: Britain’s bicycle manufacturing industry and the popularity of cycling in Britain. Forerunners of the modern bicycle; the manufacture of bicycles; and annual cross country cycle race and the International Cycle Rally. No other credits available.

results.title: Ride for your life
results.creator_credit: Robin Spry, John Kemeny and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Profile on Mike Duff, a Canadian motor cycle racer, and the sport that nearly killed him. After a near fatal crash in Japan and extensive surgery and therapy, he returned to racing and two victories in Canada. Duff explains that he will soon give up racing, which anually takes its toll of lives of friends, and competitors. First though, his goal is world championship.

results.title: Rice Farming [B&W]
results.creator_credit: Jean Halliday, Lex Halliday and Australian Instructional Films
results.brief_description: Classroom film on the Australian rice industry: rice growing in Murrumbidgee irrigation area; preparation of the fields; mechanised sowing in the spring; subsequent flooding of paddy fields until harvesting seven months later; harvesting the crop yielding fifty bags to the acre; complementary crops grown on rice farms during winter; milling processes including sifting, removing full, polishing and bagging at local mills. Half the annual rice crop satisfies the home market; the remainder is exported principally in unpolished form.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jean Halliday, Lex Halliday and Australian Instructional Films

results.title: Rice
results.creator_credit: Wheaton Galentine, Willard Van Dyke and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description: Discusses the importance of rice in the life and culture of the people of Asia, pointing out that primitive methods cannot produce enough food for Asia’s rapidly increasing population. Describes the work of two American foundations which have established a research and training centre to assist Asian farmers increase their yield. Written by Howard Enders Narrated by John Connell.

results.title: Rhodesia and Nyasaland today
results.creator_credit: Gordon Bradley, Associated Television and Rank Organisation Film Productions
results.brief_description: Surveys the progress and problems of Rhodesia and Nyasaland; the African quarter of Harari; tobacco plantations; Government farming schemes; industrial training; Victoria Falls; Kariba power station; Nyasaland’s tea production. Transition of Africans from their way of life to the European pattern.
